p.text: Application by Danso-Coffey for a declaration that she was never a director of Danso Enterprises Ltd. and was not liable for any amounts owed by the company. The application was brought after the Minister of Revenue issued a Notice of Assessment against Danso-Coffey for unpaid retail sales tax of $64,020 that was owed by the company. The company went bankrupt and the Minister identified Danso-Coffey as a registered director, based on the relevant provincial records. The company was incorporated by Danso-Coffey's brother in 1997. She was not involved in the incorporation and never signed any documentation regarding the company's incorporation or operations. She was named as a director without her knowledge. Shares were placed in her name but she never received them. Danso-Coffey did not learn that she was named as a director and shareholder until 2004. Once she received the Notice of Assessment she filed a Notice of Objection. It was declined by the Minister because it was filed after the statutory deadline for doing so. The Minister claimed the requested declaratory relief was not available because Danso-Coffey did not follow the objection and appeal route for the assessment contained in the Retail Sales Tax Act.
HELD: Application allowed.

The affidavit material clearly established that Danso-Coffey was never a director. She was never a director because she had not been appointed by the shareholders and did not provide her written consent to act, which were both required under the Business Corporations Act. She was, in fact, a complete stranger to the business. The Court had discretion to grant the requested declaration. The comprehensive statutory scheme in the Retail Sales Tax Act did not contemplate the defence that Danso-Coffey did not have the status of a director. In these unusual circumstances she could not be lawfully assessed as a director. Neither could it be said that she had any due diligence obligation. There was nothing in the Retail Sales Tax Act to prevent the Court from exercising its inherent and statutory jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief to Danso-Coffey. This would avoid the manifestly unfair result of her being assessed for taxes owed in circumstances where she was not a director.
Budget Measures Act, 2006 (No. 2), S.O. 2006, c. 33, Schedule Z.4, s. 6
Business Corporations Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. B.16, s. 119(4), s. 119(9)
Corporations Information Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. C.39, s. 2, s. 20, s. 20(2)
Courts of Justice Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. C.43, s. 97
Ontario Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 14, Rule 14.05(3)
Securities Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. S.5,
Heather J. Williams, for the Applicant.
Anita C. Veiga, for the Respondent.

The Minister of Revenue (the Minister) issued a Notice of Assessment against the applicant on May 15, 2006 under section 43 of the Retail Sales Tax Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. R-31 (RSTA), claiming a total amount of $64,020.78. This amount was initially due from an Ontario corporation, Danso Enterprises Ltd. (the company) as a result of the company's failure to remit retail sales tax. The company subsequently went bankrupt and the assessment against the applicant ensued because the Minister identified her as a registered director of the company, as disclosed in the relevant provincial records.

The applicant seeks a declaration from this court that she was never a director of the company and that she is therefore not liable to the Minister for any amounts owed to it by the company. The Minister argues that the requested declaratory relief is not available to the applicant because she has not followed the objection and appeal route in relation to the assessment under sections 24 and 25 of the RSTA, which is said to be a complete code for appeals arising under the RSTA. The applicant missed the limitation periods under the RSTA to deliver an objection to the Notice of Assessment and to request an extension of time to file the objection, due to the inadvertence of her former solicitor.
The issues to be decided are the following:
Was the applicant ever a director of the company?

If not, was the applicant nevertheless required to contest the "section 43 director's liability assessment" made against her by the Minister, under the provisions of the RSTA including compliance with the time limits for filing objections set out therein?

In any event, does the court retain a discretion to grant declaratory relief as to the applicant's status as a director and her consequent liability for retail sales tax under the RSTA, and should such discretion be exercised in the applicant's favour in the circumstances of this case?

I am of the opinion that the affidavit material before this court establishes quite clearly that the applicant was never a director of the company. The Minister's position, as I understand it, is that the applicant can be assessed as a director of the company because she is presumed or deemed to be a director by reason of the fact that she was registered as such for the relevant period (1997-2004) in the records of the Minister of Consumer and Business Services, pursuant to section 2 of the Corporations Information Act (CIA) R.S.O. 1990, c. C-39. Section 20 authorizes the Minister of Consumer and Business Services to issue a certificate or to certify any fact in the CIA. Subsection 20(2) provides that such a certificate shall be received in evidence in proceedings as proof, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, of the facts so certified.

The applicant has presented evidence to the contrary before this court. I note that the Minister has not submitted that such evidence requires a trial of this application. Instead, the argument presented is that the applicant was required to submit her argument (that she was never a director) by way of objection and appeal under the RSTA, but failed to do so within the prescribed limitation periods and is therefore barred from advancing this defence by alternative means, such as by seeking declaratory relief.

The uncontradicted evidence is that the applicant's brother incorporated the company in 1997. The applicant was not involved in the incorporation and never signed any forms or paperwork in relation to the company's incorporation or its operations. She was named a director of the corporation without her knowledge. Shares in the company were placed in her name but she never received them. In particular, she did not sign any of the following incorporation documents:
Consent to act as director
Consent to non-appointment of auditors
Resolution of Shareholders of Danso Enterprises Ltd.
By-law No. 1 and No. 2
Initial Share Subscription and
Share Certificates
The applicant was not employed by and had no operational involvement in the business at any time, nor did she ever receive any income or benefits from the company.

In 2004, the company became insolvent and eventually filed for bankruptcy. In the summer of 2004, the applicant learned that she had been named as a director and shareholder of the company. This company was inactive between 1997 and 2002. In 2002, the company purchased a restaurant franchise and, as noted, in April 2004, it was petitioned into bankruptcy. Shortly thereafter the applicant learned that she had been named a director of the company and she retained a solicitor to determine if she could be personally liable for the debts of the company. On advice of this solicitor, she filed a Notice of Change form with the Ministry of Commercial Affairs, removing her registration as a director of the company.

In January 2005, the applicant received a letter from the Ministry of Finance advising her that the company had failed to file retail sales tax returns and that it had failed to pay assessments when due. The letter stated that the applicant was personally liable, as a director, for the company's outstanding retail sales tax arrears. In May 2006, the applicant received a Notice of Assessment for the company's retail sales tax arrears. That notice stated that she owed $64,020.78 to the Ministry of Finance for the company's unremitted retails sales tax arrears. Upon receiving that notice, the applicant instructed her solicitor to file a Notice of Objection to the May 2006 Notice of Assessment. However, the Notice of Objection was declined by the Minister because it was filed after the statutory deadline for doing so. A subsequent request for an extension of time to file the objection was declined as well, also for being out of time.

As a result of the missed limitation, the Minister did not made any determination or ruling on the applicant's position that she was never a director of the company. Counsel for the Minister submitted in argument that but for the missed limitation period for filing an objection, the applicant could have contested her status as a director and also put forward a due diligence defence to the director's liability assessment that had been filed against her. The relevant provision of the RSTA is section 43, which provides:

43(1) "Where a corporation has failed to collect tax or has collected tax and failed to remit the tax or has failed to pay any interest or penalty relating thereto, the directors of the corporation at the time the corporation was required to collect or remit the taxes or to pay the interest or penalty relating thereto, are jointly and severally liable, together with the corporation, to pay such amounts." [emphasis added]
43(2) "A director of a corporation is not liable under subsection (1) unless,

the corporation has become a bankrupt due to an assignment or receiving order or it has filed either a notice of intention to file or a proposal under the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act (Canada), and a claim for the amount of the corporation's liability referred to in subsection (1) has been proved within six months after the date of the assignment, receiving order or filing of the proposal."

43(3) "A director of a corporation is not liable for a failure described under subsection (1) if the director exercised the degree of care, diligence and skill to prevent the failure that a reasonably prudent person would have exercised in comparable circumstances."

43(4) The Minister may assess any person for any amount payable by the person under this section and, where the Minister sends a notice of assessment, the sections of this Act respecting assessments, objections and appeals apply with such modifications as the circumstances require.

43(5) Any assessment under subsection (4) of any amount payable by a person who is a director of a corporation shall not be made more than two years after the person last ceased to be a director of the corporation ." [emphasis added]

Section 43 of the RSTA imposes a joint and several liability on directors of a company for uncollected or unremitted retail sales tax, but this obligation is clearly dependent on the individual having the status of director at the material times. A non-director has no obligations under the section. Furthermore, section 43(3) places on the director a duty to exercise a "degree of care, diligence and skill" to prevent the failure to collect and remit taxes. It would therefore make no sense to require a non-director to establish the statutory due diligence defence because a non-director has no obligation of due diligence under the RSTA.

In assessing whether the applicant was ever in fact a director of the company, there are two requirements that must be met in order to become a director of an Ontario corporation. They are contained in sections 119(4) and 119(9) of the Business Corporations Act R.S.O. 1990, c. B-16. Section 119(4) of that Act states that the directors of a corporation shall be elected by the shareholders:

(4) Subject to clause 120(a), shareholders of a corporation shall elect, at the first meeting of shareholders and at each succeeding annual meeting at which an election of directors is required, directors to hold office for a term expiring not later than the close of the third annual meeting of shareholders following the election.
Section 119(9) of the Act sets out the requirement that an individual director must, in order to become a director, provide her consent, in writing, to her appointment:

(9) Subject to subsection (10), the election or appointment of a director under this Act is not effective unless the person elected or appointed consents in writing before or within 10 days after the date of the election or appointment.

While the word "director" is not specifically defined in the RSTA, it is appropriate in my view to look to the above quoted sections 119(4) and 119(9) of the Business Corporations Act. The RSTA and the Business Corporations Act are statutes enacted by the legislature on the same subject and are therefore assumed to operate together to create a single regulatory scheme, see Ruth Sullivan, Dreidger on the Construction of Statutes, 3d ed. (Toronto: Butterworths, 1995).

In a case very much on point, the Tax Court of Canada, in Pereira v. The Queen, [2008] 3 C.T.C. 2154 was required to determine whether the appellant was a director of the company in the context of a director's liability assessment for unremitted income tax. The appellant was a bricklayer actively involved in the business who had signed minutes of director's meetings. However the court focused on the fact that the appellant was not elected by shareholders of the company as required by section 119(4) of the Business Corporations Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. B-16 and no written consent was given by the appellant to his appointment as a director as contemplated by s. 119(9) of the Act. The court concluded that the appellant was not a director and therefore not personally liable for the unremitted tax.

I would follow the Pereira decision and hold that the applicant here was never a director of the company because she had never been appointed by the shareholders nor had she provided her written consent to act, both of which are required by the Business Corporations Act. Indeed, this is a clearer case than Pereira because the applicant was not operationally or administratively involved in the company's business in any way. She was, in fact, a complete stranger to the business, her only connection being the family relationship with her brother.

Having concluded that the applicant was never a director of the company, and in the face of the obvious injustice of holding her personally liable for the sum of $64,000 in taxes that were not remitted through no lack of diligence on her part, does this court have the discretion to grant a declaration that she was not a director and is not liable for the company's retail sales tax arrears?

The Minister submits that the RSTA is a complete code and provides a procedure for a remedy against all disputed assessments. It is argued that the court should not grant a declaration that is inconsistent with the remedy provided for in sections 24 and 25 of the RSTA, which set out the objection and appeal routes, and the limitations for seeking extensions of time. In asking for a declaration to extinguish her debt by way of a Rule 14 procedure, the applicant is said to be attempting "... to use the route through section 97 of the Courts of Justice Act to achieve indirectly what [she] is not able to do directly through [the RSTA]", see Scion Capital, LLC v. Gold Fields Ltd, (2006), 15 B.L.R. (4th) 331 (Sup.Ct.), at paras. 33-36. This case is discussed below.
Sections 24 and 25 of the RSTA provide as follows:

24.(1)A person who objects to an assessment made against the person under section 18, subsection 19(1) or section 20 or to a statement under section 20 that is served on the person may, within 180 days from the day of mailing of the statement or notice of assessment, serve on the Minister a notice of objection in the form approved by the Minister.

text.emph: Facts and reasons to be given

p.text: (1.1) The notice of objection shall,
clearly describe each issue raised by way of objection; and
fully set out the facts and reasons relied on by the person in respect of each issue.

(1.2) If a notice of objection does not fully set out the facts and reasons relied on by the person in respect of an issue, the Minister may in writing request the person to provide the information, and the person shall be deemed to have complied with clause (1.1)(b) in respect of the issue if the person provides the information to the Minister in writing within 60 days after the day the request is made by the Minister.

(1.3) A person shall not raise, by way of objection under this section to a fresh statement or reassessment or to a variation of an assessment or statement under subsection (4), any issue that the person is not entitled to raise by way of appeal under section 25 in respect of the fresh statement or reassessment or of a variation of the assessment or statement. 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 8(1).

(2) A notice of objection under this section shall be served by being sent by registered mail addressed to the Minister or by such other method of service as the Minister prescribes. R.S.O. 1990, c. R.31, s. 24(2); 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 8(2).

(3) For the purpose of calculating the number of days mentioned in subsection (1), (1.2) or 25(1), the day on which a notice of assessment or statement is mailed under subsection (1), a request is made under subsection (1.2) or a notification is given under subsection (4) is the date stated in the notice of assessment, statement, request or notification. 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 8(3).

(4) Upon receipt of the notice of objection, the Minister shall with all due dispatch reconsider the assessment or statement objected to and vacate, confirm or vary the assessment or statement, or reassess or serve a fresh statement, and the Minister shall thereupon notify the person making the objection of his or her action in writing. R.S.O. 1990, c. R.31, s. 24(4); 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 8(4).

25.(1) When the Minister has given the notification required by subsection 24(4), the person who has served a notice of objection under that section may appeal to the Superior Court of Justice to have the assessment or statement so objected to vacated or varied, but no appeal under this section shall be instituted after the expiration of ninety days from the day notice has been mailed to such person under subsection 24(4). R.S.O. 1990, c. R.31, s. 25(1); 2001, c. 23, s. 198(1).
(2) An appeal to the Superior Court of Justice shall be instituted by,
filing a notice of appeal with the court in the form approved by the Minister;
paying a fee to the court in the same amount and manner as the fee payable under regulations made under the Administration of Justice Act on the issue of a statement of claim; and
serving on the Minister a copy of the notice of appeal as filed. 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 9; 2001, c. 23, s. 198(2).

(2.1) A person is entitled to raise by way of appeal only those issues raised by the person in a notice of objection to the assessment being appealed and in respect of which the person has complied or was deemed to have complied with subsection 24(1.1). 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 9.

(2.2) Despite subsection (2.1), a person may raise by way of appeal an issue forming the basis of a fresh statement or reassessment or of a variation of an assessment or statement under subsection 24(4) if the issue was not part of the assessment or statement with respect to which the person served the notice of objection. 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 9.
(2.3) Subsections (2.1) and (2.2) apply only in respect of appeals in respect of which the period of 90 days referred to in subsection (1) begins after December 31, 1997. 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 9.

text.emph: Waived right of objection or appeal

p.text: (2.4) Despite subsection (1), no person shall institute an appeal under this section to have an assessment or statement vacated or varied in respect of an issue for which the right of objection or appeal has been waived in writing by or on behalf of the person. 1997, c. 43, Sched. D, s. 9.
(3) A notice of appeal shall be served on the Minister by being sent by registered mail addressed to the Minister. R.S.O. 1990, c. R.31, s. 25(3).

(4) The person appealing shall set out in the notice of appeal a statement of the allegations of fact and the statutory provisions and reasons that the person intends to submit in supporting the appeal. R.S.O. 1990, c. R.31, s. 25(4).
(5) The time within which a notice of objection is to be served or an appeal is to be instituted may be extended by the Minister if application for extension is made,
in respect of a notice of objection under subsection 24(1),
before the expiration of the time allowed under that subsection for service of notice of the objection, or

within one year from the day of mailing or delivery by personal service of the notice of assessment or statement of disallowance that is the subject of the objection where the person wishing to make objection furnishes to the Minister an explanation satisfactory to the Minister that explains why the notice of objection could not be served in accordance with subsection 24(1); or
with respect to an appeal, before the expiry of the time allowed under subsection (1) for instituting the appeal. R.S.O. 1990, c. R.31, s. 25(5); 2006, c. 33, Sched. Z.4, s. 5.

In Scion, supra, Morawetz J. refused to grant a declaration that the defendants acted in contravention of the insider trading provisions of the Securities Act R.S.O. 1990, c. S-5. His refusal to grant declaratory relief was based on the fact that the Act sets out a procedure for bringing a civil action for breach of these provisions. He held that, in the circumstances, the remedy sought was inconsistent with the statutory remedy provided, and reliance on the court's inherent jurisdiction was not appropriate because there was no functional gap in the legislation. Morawetz J. stated at paragraphs 33 to 36:

The Applicants submit that the court has discretion to grant the requested declaration, both under its inherent jurisdiction and under section 97 of the Courts of Justice Act, which provides that this court "may make binding declarations of right, whether or not any consequential relief is or could be claimed."

The term inherent jurisdiction was recently the subject of comment by the Court of Appeal in Stelco Inc., Re(2005), 75 O.R. (3d) 5 (Ont. C.A.). There is a distinction between inherent jurisdiction and statutory discretion. Inherent jurisdiction is a power derived from the very nature of the court as a superior court of law, permitting the court to maintain its authority and to prevent its process being obstructed and abused. In Stelco Inc., Re, the Court of Appeal, at para. 35, states:

In spite of the expansive nature of this power, inherent jurisdiction does not operate where Parliament or the legislature has acted. As Farley J. noted in Royal Oak Mines, supra, inherent jurisdiction is "not limitless; if the legislative body has not left a functional gap or vacuum, then inherent jurisdiction should not be brought into play" [citations omitted].

This is not a case for relying on the court's inherent jurisdiction as the OSA establishes a procedure with respect to civil actions as a remedy for insider trading. This procedure is contained in sections 134 and 135 of the OSA. There is no functional gap or vacuum.

The OSA has clearly set out a procedure for commencing proceedings in respect of civil actions for breach of the insider trading provisions. The remedy referenced is contained in section 134 and is one of damages. In this case, the remedy sought is not one of damages, but is a declaration, together with the direction that the Respondents are required to dispose of certain securities and that they be prohibited in dealing in such securities for a period of 12 months following the relief granted.

The remedy sought by the Applicants is not consistent with the remedy provided for in section 134. The Applicants are attempting to use the route through section 97 of the Courts of Justice Act to achieve indirectly what it is not able to do directly through section 135. Sections 134 and 135 provide the remedy of damages as a result of trading with insider knowledge. The Applicants are not in a position to show that it has suffered damages. The Applicants actually bought shares during the period that the alleged insider trading took place. The Applicants did not suffer as a result of the Respondents buying shares. On the contrary, the price of the shares increased. There is no reference to a declaration as being a remedy for insider trading in the OSA. It is not appropriate to seek a remedy other than damages. Since the Applicants did not suffer any damages, they are seeking a remedy in the form of a declaration that is not available in law.

The Minister also relies on Cheong v. Ontario (Minister of Finance), [2004] O.J. No. 378 (C.A.). In Cheong, the taxpayer brought a motion, at first instance, to the Superior Court and sought an extension of time for service of an appeal under subsection 25(5) of the RSTA. This is the same general provision at issue in this application. On an appeal from the dismissal of the taxpayer's motion, the Court of Appeal denied the extension for service of the appeal, which was served one day late, and stated as follows:

[30] The cases cited by the appellant do not support a conclusion that section 29 of the RSTA allows the appellant access to the court's practices and procedure to extend the time to serve the notice of appeal after the statutory limitation period has expired. Unlike [reference to case law omitted], this is not a case where estoppel can be raised against the Minister. And, unlike K.C. v. College of Physical Therapists of Alberta, [1998] A.J. No. 99 (C.A.) at para. 12 in this case, the statutory right of appeal in s. 25(1) of the RSTA is clearly conditional on the appeal being instituted within the ninety day limitation period.

[31] The inability of the court to relieve against the ninety day limitation period that results from this statutory interpretation may seem to carry draconian results. Indeed, as Iacobucci and Major JJ. wrote in their dissenting opinion in Novak v. Bond, [1999] 1 S.C.R. 808 at para. 8: "Almost all applications of limitations statutes will seem harsh. But their finality should not obscure their value. [emphasis added]

More recently, in Joseph v. Paramount Canada's Wonderland (2007), 87 O.R. (3d) 473 the Court of Appeal confirmed that even the common law doctrine of special circumstances cannot be used to extend statutory limitation periods in order to allow an action to be commenced after the expiry of same.

It should be noted that Cheong dealt with the late filing of a notice of appeal to a section 43 director's liability assessment. In contrast to the case at bar, the appellant was a director of the company and his status as such was not contested. He unsuccessfully sought an extension of time to appeal in order to put forward what the court referred to as "a detailed due diligence defence to the assessment" in what were described as "sympathetic circumstances". I certainly accept that Cheong makes it clear that the Superior Court has no inherent jurisdiction to extend the time limitations in the RSTA in the face of a comprehensive statutory appeal procedure. And as Morawetz J. stated in Scion, declaratory relief is not available where it would be inconsistent with a statutory scheme of relief or remedies.

In the present case, I think it is doubtful that the applicant could have objected to the director's liability assessment against her on any basis other than that she exercised due diligence in the circumstances and was thus in compliance with section 43(3) of the RSTA. The comprehensive statutory scheme in the RSTA does not contemplate the defence that the applicant did not, in fact, have the status of director. The statutory scheme in sections 24 and 25 of the RSTA does not countenance the defence that I have found to be factually established before this court that she was never a director. In these unusual circumstances, it must follow that the applicant cannot be lawfully assessed as a director under section 43 of the RTSA, nor can she be said to have any due diligence obligation under section 43(3) of the Act. She was, in effect, a stranger to the company.

Counsel for the Minister submitted in argument that the applicant, had she filed a notice of objection in time, could have raised the defence that she did not have the status of director and was therefore not liable for tax under section 43(3) of the RSTA. I do not think this is correct. Rather the situation is as stated in paragraph 76 of the Minister's factum:

A director who has been assessed under section 43 of the RSTA may raise the statutory defence, which is often described as the due diligence defence, pursuant to subsection 43(3) at the Ministry's initial review process, where a person has delivered a valid Objection, or at the Appeal stage on the delivery of a valid Appeal.

"A director of a corporation is not liable for a failure described under subsection (1) if the director exercised the degree of care, diligence and skill to prevent the failure that a reasonably prudent person would have exercised in comparable circumstances."
and in the Minister's January 19, 2005 letter to the applicant, which is before the court:
As a director of the above corporation you may be held liable for the corporation's current and future liability and payment of the liability to the Minister of Finance.

To assist you in determining your potential liability we would inform you of the "due diligence" defence offered under Subsection 43(3). This subsection provides that a director is not liable where he/she has exercised the degree of care, diligence and skill to prevent the failure that a reasonably prudent person would have exercised in comparable circumstances.

If you are of the opinion you are not liable and an assessment should not be raised against you, please provide written reasons and supporting documents which, you believe, demonstrate you are not responsible for the outstanding debt.

Please return this information to our office within 30 days from the date of this letter. Your submission should include factual information concerning actions you took to prevent and safeguard against your company's failure to remit taxes owing.

In my opinion, there was nothing in the RSTA, at the material times, to prevent this court from exercising its inherent and statutory jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief to the applicant. This would avoid the manifestly unfair result of the applicant being assessed as a company director for taxes owed in the sum of $64,000 in circumstances where she was not a director. There was nothing in the statutory scheme in sections 24 and 25 of the RSTA to prevent the exercise of the court's jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief on the principles stated by the Court of Appeal in 80 Wellesley St. East Ltd. V. Fundy Bay Builders Ltd. [1972] 2 O.R. 280 (C.A.)at paragraph 9:

As a superior Court of general jurisdiction, the Supreme Court of Ontario has all of the powers that are necessary to do justice between the parties. Except where provided specifically to the contrary, the Court's jurisdiction is unlimited and unrestricted in substantive law in civil matters. In Re Michie Estate and City of Toronto et al., [1968] 1 O.R. 266 at pp. 268-9, 66 D.L.R. 92d) 213 at pp. 215-6, Stark J., after considering the relevant provisions of the Judicature Act and the authorities, said:

It appears clear that the Supreme Court of Ontario has broad universal jurisdiction over all matters of substantive law unless the Legislature divests from this universal jurisdiction by legislation in unequivocal terms. The rule of law relating to the jurisdiction of superior Courts was laid down at least as early as 1667 in the case of Peacock v. Bell and Kendall (1667), 1 Wms. Saund. 73 at p. 74, 85 E.R. 84:

... And the rule for jurisdiction is, that nothing shall be intended to be out of the jurisdiction of a Superior Court, but that which specifically appears to be so; and, on the contrary, nothing shall be intended to be within the jurisdiction of an Inferior Court but that which is so expressly alleged.

The court's discretion may well be exercised differently in future by reason of the enactment of the Budget Measures Act, 2006 (No. 2), S.O. 2006, c. 33, Sch. Z.4, amending the Retail Sales Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. R-31 which amendments came into force on December 20, 2006.

text.emph: 6. The Act is amended by adding the following section:
Application under subrule 14.05(2), Rules of Civil Procedure

p.text: 29.1(1) If the following conditions are satisfied, a person may make an application under subrule 14.05(2) of the Rules of Civil Procedure to a judge of the Superior Court of Justice:
The application is to determine one or more issues of law that depend solely on the interpretation of,
this Act or the regulations, or
this Act or the regulations and another Ontario statute or regulation.
The Minister has indicated in writing that the Minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest for the applicant to make the application.
The Minister and the applicant have executed a statement of agreed facts on which they both intend to rely and the applicant files the statement as part of the applicant's application record.
No facts remain in dispute between the Minister and the applicant that either of them believes may be relevant to the determination of any issue of law that is a subject of the application.

text.emph: Application of rule 38.10, Rules of Civil Procedure

p.text: Rule 38.10 of the Rules of Civil Procedure does not apply to an application referred to in this section, except that the presiding judge may, on the hearing of the application, adjourn the application in whole or in part and with or without terms under clause 38.10(1)(a).
The court may dispose of an application that is authorized under this section by,
making a declaration of law in respect of one or more issues of law forming the subject of the application;
declining to make a declaration of law in respect of any of the issues of law forming the subject of the application; or
dismissing the application.
No declaration of law made on an application under this section,
shall be binding on the Minister and the applicant except in relation to the facts agreed to by them in the proceeding; or
shall otherwise affect the rights of the Minister or the applicant in any appeal instituted under this Act.

(5) No person other than the Minister may bring an application under subrule 14.05(3) of the Rules of Civil Procedure on or after the day this section comes into force, in respect of any matter arising under this Act. [emphasis added]

On the motion of the Minister, the court shall dismiss a proceeding commenced by an application under rule 14.05 of the Rules of Civil Procedure relating to a matter under this Act or the regulations if any condition in subsection (1) has not been satisfied or the application is prohibited under subsection (5).

It may be that subsection 29.1(5) will preclude all applications such as this under subrule 14.05(3) by persons other than the Minister, if the matter is "in respect of any matter arising under this Act (the RSTA)." However, applying the rule of statutory interpretation expressio unius est exclusio alterius, I would conclude that there was no such limitation at the time of the assessment in issue. Section 29.1 should not be interpreted as having retroactive application because it affects taxpayers' substantive rights. The requirement that any matter arising under the RSTA proceed under the provisions of the RSTA was not in force at the time of the assessment in question. Therefore I would not regard a declaration as to the applicant's status as a director as being inconsistent with the statutory scheme. At least at the time of this assessment, the RSTA was not, in my opinion, a sufficiently comprehensive or exclusive scheme so as to oust this court's jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief, see Merrifield v. Canada (Attorney General) [2008] O.J. No. 2730.

I note that the Minister made an earlier motion in this proceeding under section 29.1 of the RSTA seeking to strike out the applicant's claim on the basis of non-compliance with section 29.1. McLean J. dismissed the motion stating:

Section 29.1 does not specifically restrict an application being made that a person was not a director within the common law or under the Business Corporations Act. The argument may be made before the hearing judge about the exercise of discretion, but on this record the Court is not convinced that this is an abuse of process under Rule 25. The application may proceed and argument about the substantive nature of the application may be made then.
McLean J.'s order was not appealed and I respectfully agree with his observations.

In summary, on the facts of this unusual case, the court will exercise its discretion to declare that the applicant was never a director of the company and is accordingly not liable for the section 43 RSTA director's liability assessment dated May 15, 2006.

If the applicant is seeking costs, she should serve and file a brief written submission within fourteen days of the release of this decision and the Minister will reply within fourteen days thereafter.
C.T. HACKLAND J.
